ValueDomain.preferredName: Hematopoietic Growth Factor  Most Recent Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The type of most recent Hematopoietic Growth Factor received by the patient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Expressed in platelets, human Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF/VEGF Family) is a mitogenic factor for mesenchymal cells characterized by a motif of eight cysteines and released upon wounding to stimulate adjacent cell growth. PDGF can exist as antiparallel disulfide-linked homodimers (PDGFA, PDGFB) or heterodimers (PDGFA/PDGFB) that bind to PDGF receptor and elicit a variety of cellular responses. A and B homodimers are implicated in transformation processes. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: A family of growth factors that act as potent mitogens and are involved in the stimulation of angiogenesis. There are four members of this family (platelet-derived growth factor A, B, C and D) that are characterized by a core motif of eight cysteines. They bind to their cognate receptor tyrosine kinases (platelet-derived growth factor receptor family) as homodimers or heterodimers to stimulate signaling.
